Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel Voltammetric Biosensor Design to Promote Interest and Inquiry-Based Learning in Electrochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Leslie Sombers of North Carolina State University and her graduate student researchers will be supported to investigate the use of fast-scan cyclic voltammetry to monitor the enzymatic generation of hydrogen peroxide with carbon-fiber microelectrodes. The approach that Prof. Sombers and her students are developing will be used to measure the presence and dynamics of specific, non-electroactive analytes in biological tissue. For her integrated educational project, Prof. Sombers will work with her students to develop a presentation to be given to the public at the North Carolina Museum of Science on the use of electrochemistry, as well as working with North Carolina State's Science House on developing hands-on materials for use in K-12 education.

In situ detection of biologically active molecules is important in helping to innovate in biology, neuroscience and medicine. The kind of work that Prof. Sombers and her students are developing will allow researchers in these fields to make chemical measurements in relatively un-perturbed living systems. This is important in answering fundamental questions that can lead to new understandings of the operations of living systems, as well as developing new approaches to medicine. The graduate students working on this project will gain useful inter-disciplinary experience at the intersection of biology, chemistry and electronics. Prof. Sombers will also continue her efforts at increasing the opportunities for students from underrepresented groups to participate in the STEM enterprise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sensor and biosensor design is an interdisciplinary research area targeted for continuous investments to ensure the advancement of this technology in point-of-care diagnostics, as well as penetration into new markets such as security, military biodefense, environmental monitoring and the process industry.  This project has exploited analytical electrochemistry and spectroscopy to address a critical need for sensors capable of measuring the dynamics of non-electroactive molecules with high sensitivity, electrochemical selectivity and a rapid response time. The results have enabled real-time chemical analyses of unprecedented quality and scope.  This work has also served to promote interest in science in general, and electrochemistry in particular, among the general population.

We have investigated how the fundamental surface properties of carbon-fiber microelectrodes underlie the voltammetric detection of H2O2. H2O2 electrochemistry dictates the performance of peroxidase-based biosensors, and thus it is of significant interest to scientists developing technologies for rapid molecular monitoring. Despite wide interest in exploiting this electrochemistry, the precise mechanisms that describe H2O2 redox activity at various electrode surfaces are not well understood.  Further, the effects of potential on the chemical and structural nature of the sensing surface also not well understood. We have used a variety of electrochemical and spectroscopic approaches to advance our understanding of the chemical processes occurring at the electrode surface.  We have studied how oxidation of the surface with an air plasma, or electrochemical conditioning of the carbon, can serve to structurally alter the carbon microstructure and improve electrochemical detection. Spectroelectrochemical characterization of the carbon surface demonstrated a dynamic carbon structure that quickly responds to the application of potential (seconds).  A reliable plasma-etching procedure was developed and used to create a recessed disk electrode geometry.  This limits mass transport at the electrode surface, enhancing sensitivity. A nanoscale electrode was used to monitor fluctuations of catecholamines and reactive oxygen species inside of single chromaffin cells using both amperometry and voltammetry.  To the best of our knowledge, this is the first voltammetric study of intracellular neurochemicals. Using fast-scan cyclic voltammetry, we have enabled the selective detection of brain glucose dynamics in real time and the simultaneous detection of glucose and dopamine dynamics at a single recording site, and we have quantitiatively compared several enzyme immobilization strategies.  Finally, we have extended this technology to the detection of choline and lactate. Our approach to molecular monitoring is revolutionary because it permits the sensitive and selective real-time detection of dynamic fluctuations of non-electroactive glucose at a single, micrometer-scale recording site without the need for the complicated coatings or self-referencing subtraction schemes that are typically required with amperometric detection in biological samples using enzyme-modified electrodes.  Overall, the results of this project can be used to facilitate studies investigating innumerable biological questions that have been left unanswered to date.

In addition to the fundamental science, we presented several interactive exhibits that describe our research at public venues, including museums and street fairs. We developed and presented week-long chemistry workshops for teachers of grades 3-5 and 6-8 in Lee County, NC. We have visited classrooms, and have hosted visiting students in our own lab for question and answer sessions. Collectively, these outreach efforts have served to inspire enthusiasm and confidence in science learners of all ages, helping to create a better-informed community. We have published 7 manuscripts. 18 undergraduate student presentations and 33 graduate student presentations were delivered at major scientific conferences.  The PI delivered 15 major presentations on this work. All stated goals were met.
